title.rendered: Common eCommerce Mistakes And How To Avoid Them

content.rendered:
Running an eCommerce business can be a fantastic option these days – it’s what customers want, and it comes with plenty of benefits. However, just because it might seem like quite a simple thing to do as long as you’ve got a website and some social media happening, the truth is that there’s just as much to think about (and maybe more) as if you had a brick and mortar store, and it’s easy to make mistakes. 

The problem is that whereas in real life mistakes can often be rectified without too much damage done, when it comes to your eCommerce business, that might not be the case, and one mistake could spell disaster. With that in mind, here are some common eCommerce mistakes and how to avoid them – read on to find out more. 

Ignoring Mobile Optimization

It’s 2024, and most people shop on their phones, not on a computer (or at least they’ll browse on their phones and then make the final purchase on their computer), and if your website isn’t mobile-friendly, you’re essentially losing customers before they even get to the checkout page. Tiny text, slow loading times, challenging (to put it politely) navigation… it all causes frustration that could send your potential customers directly to your competitors. 

That’s why you need to use responsive design to make sure your website works properly on any device, whatever the size of the screen. It’s wise to test your website on a range of screen sizes from time to time to ensure it’s doing what it’s meant to do and so you can keep on top of things, just in case. 

Making The Checkout Process Complicated

Even if your site is great and a customer has chosen what they wanted and is ready to pay, you can still lose them right at the last second if you’ve got a complicated checkout experience – that could include things like too many steps, making them create an account, limited payment options, and so on. 

The fix is to simplify the checkout process as much as possible, so let people check out as guests if they want to, and always make sure you offer plenty of payment options so everyone is happy. And it has to be secure as well otherwise you’ll lose trust and that’s never a good thing. It’s a good idea to learn all about payment processing because the more you know, the better the checkout experience will be for your customers. 

Skipping Product Descriptions 

Have you ever landed on a product page and it’s just a photo and a price? If so, you’ll know that’s not enough – as a customer, you want more than that, especially if the price is a high one (but it’s the same principle for all products). After all, how are you going to know that what you’re buying is the right thing or worth the money if there’s no information? Customers will either just decide not to bother or they’ll go to another site to learn more, and probably end up buying there instead. 

That’s why you need to write clear, engaging, accurate, and detailed product descriptions – make sure you highlight key features, talk about benefits, and mention any specific unique selling points – and if you can include a video showing how it works, that’s even better.
